Also koalas which can be tamed with leaves (you should be able to craft individual leaves by putting a block of leaves in a crafting table) and will climb on your back and add an extra inventory (that's in another post, I just had to add it here).  Maybe also Hyenas to kill the koalas.  They should be neutral to players but hostile to koalas.  Also ox.  They should kill giraffe and can kill you in a stampede. 

Also, more flowers. 

CHAIRS.  And there should be four-poster beds made with sticks, carpets, and 2 beds.  You should be able to put food on TABLES, which would be crafted with sticks and planks. 

And you should add deer.  Ox and deer should, like goats, ram into trees if provoked and led to the tree, and drop horns. 

Also add curtains that should change the color of the light wafting through windows. 

CUSTOM PAINTINGS, made with a canvas, which is a painting crafted with some sticks.  There should be paint made with dye and water.  And a paintbrush, which is made with sticks and fur that should be dropped by animals when they die.  That's it.
You need to post each suggestion individually. Skis would be nice for travelling down mountains, but everything else isn't really necessary.
Okay.

You're basically just posting random ideas that come across your mind. Try thinking some of these through, and you'll find that most of them will not work in Minecraft. They either won't fit the design, or will be another random mob or item that serves absolutely no unique or beneficial purpose. Minecraft is meant to have a simple set up that you can explore, expand and build on to create your own complex world(s). The majority of your suggestions just entirely miss that point. It's not a game with fixed missions or objectives either, so having seasonal events tied directly into your worlds makes absolutely no sense. It's an open world game. Try thinking feedback through before posting whatever comes into your mind, or just asking for more of certain stuff. Believe me, most of the suggestions that just pop up into your mind won't work if you don't give them a second and even third thought. Posting suggestions that come instantly to your mind makes you sound like you're meming.

to add a new tool or item that would be
The slingshot in which we can throw items at great distances so as not to be approaching something or someone

Melly Dow, I think he/she was talking about Iron blobs, not veins. Iron golem farms are more mid-game rather than early game. Any Minecraft player go mining first in order to advance enough to make an Iron farm. So having that early game mining be a little harder will make early progression harder, then by the time you’ve progressed enough to potentially make an Iron farm, you likely won’t need one because all of the cave exploration you’ve done in the early-mid-game led you to an Iron vein.

Ore veins can have more than 20,000 ore blocks, which you can more than double with Fortune III! That's not even counting the raw ore blocks you find! How is that not enough for any technical player or builder? Even the smallest ones probably have a couple hundred of minerals at least, and those ones are very occasional/rare. They're not impossible to find either, not at all. If you know what you're doing and are a dedicated cave explorer (which a lot of people will be after we get the new generation and biomes), you can find them within a few hours, and it's incredibly rewarding and satisfying when you do so, from what I heard. They're not too hard to find at all, just hard enough so that when you find them and start mining, it feels like they were well earned due to the strategy put into it. Of course, some people would still favor making Iron farms, and that's why they are there in the first place, so that every playstyle has an option. However, I heard of very few people who would make Iron farms within an hour, and even then they wouldn't be the most efficient ones at all. Usually most people go mining during the early game first until they could upgrade sufficiently to make an Iron farm that they could really rely on, since mining is the most reliable and easy way of getting resources early game (besides diamonds, probably).

For the record, the amount of Iron you find in 2 Ore Veins on average when using Fortune III should be enough to fill your entire inventory with Shulker boxes that are full of Iron ingots. You can make more than 30 Mega-Beacons/6-Beacon pyramids with that. Of course Ore Veins vary a lot, but variation is great, and on average they are relatively huge. A couple of them should provide huge amounts like so. By the time you kill the Wither once in a casual game, you would have almost certainly found at least two if you're into exploration and caving (which will become infinitely more fun). These are ridiculous amounts of Iron, so please don't try to convince me that it won't be enough to keep you set for the entirety of the game, especially since you would keep finding more throughout the game if you keep caving. Look at the numbers yourself.

Melly Dow

This is a good idea, although it's not meant to be official. That's why a warning pops up every time you use it - it could stop working anytime.

406361220471 the warning relates to the fact that the datapack has worldgen in it. There is also a warning for playing on snapshot versions (which have the same issue as the one you mentioned), so it makes sense for the datapack to have a warning as well anyway.

Malachite... is an ore of copper. And a gem. What is done with it? It is a lapidary mineral, used to make cabochons, jewelry, etc. Lapis is also a lapidary mineral. Lapis, in Minecraft, is used as a dye, and for enchanting. Maybe malachite would be used on an anvil!

Hello, this appears to be a non-English post. Below you will find a transcription of the topic being discussed.

Title: “Firefly”

Text: “The fireflies will be like flies with a small luminous yellow cube behind and wings similar to those of bees will appear in the caves from layer 7 to -56, they would be the replacement of the bats in the deep caves, they would illuminate the blocks that they touch for 2.4 seconds at a slightly lower brightness than redstone, and it will shine on its own in a 1x1 block area. It would fly, and should be similar in size to the bat, with the subtitles option it would make the sound "firefly flapping" and have a low probability of appearing (slightly less than that of bats). ”

- Translated by Admin.

How is making the ores realistic confusing or bad? This happened to make color blind people able to differentiate between different ores, so it helps a lot with accessibility. Also in terms of design, the old ores are just ugly by comparison. They all look the same, which makes absolutely no sense. Different materials should look different. That's the normal in Minecraft and not the exception. Even the mineral blocks look different from each other, except for Gold and Diamond blocks. Iron nuggets look different from gold nuggets. All of the raw ores look different. Even Netherite tools have subtle differences compared to other tools, other than when it comes to color. I'd say that all materials should have different looking blocks, armor, and very subtly different tools like with Netherite.
Apparently this is to help color blind people. There are probably texture packs you can use to get the old texture
Just imagine a red velociraptor running around in the lush caves stocking you as you explore

I find redstone ore common enough without veins existing. I often end up with a chest full of dust. Most people don't have use for such massive quantities of dust. I don't think it should be less common either. It is as common as it needs to be.
What would you make with that ores, what are the advantages to that? Make a longer version of your post, please.
Do not forget, we were accustomed to small caves ..., and after the new update, we will become accustomed to giant caves, spyglass and giant mountains ...
Also, people will become interested in making mods and people will love it, and Minecraft will become more fun, and also there are no mods for Minecraft Bedrock.

This would be a really nice addition to a build I'm working on. It's an old observatory, and this is exactly what I need! I think it would be a nice addition. Plus, since the spyglass already has a 3D block form when you hold it, it would probably look the same placed down as when you are carrying it

I really really love this idea! Imagine placing down a spyglass to create a viewpoint on top of a mountain cliffside somewhere overlooking your creation. This feels like such a natural addition to the spyglass to make it more than just an optifine zoom replacement.

I think this might just be too much. The powers of Fortune as of this snapshot were just made consistent and fair. If you think about it, it was very odd and unfair that we couldn't Fortune metal ores before. This hasn't really messed with the powers of Fortune, it just made it fair in my opinion. However, yes, enchantments (and magic) as a whole need to get rarer and more valuable, though this might be something for the near future.

I think it would be a good idea to instead of making fortune more difficult to obtain make it multiply differently with each ore.

(for example maximum and more consistent double drops for fortune 3 with iron ore, but keep all existing settings the same)
Fortune is a relatively "endgame" enchantment.

Actually we only need to mine about 75% of what we did before. Remember you can already use fortune on coal, lapis, emerald, quartz, diamond, and nether gold.

 

I agree that some enchantments should be switched to treasure (infinity, channeling, multishot, silk touch) but fortune just isn't one of them.
